title: Dermatitis: Causes, Symptoms, and Treatments
author: Stephanie Booth

sections.heading: What Is Dermatitis?
content: Dermatitis is a broad term that describes various types of skin inflammation (skin rashes). The most common early symptom is red, dry, itching skin. Severe cases can include crusty scales, painful cracks in your skin, or blisters that ooze fluid. Since a range of things can irritate your skin, your doctor will try to narrow their diagnosis to a specific kind of dermatitis. That can help them pinpoint the cause and choose the best treatment to heal your skin.
Dermatitis can cause itchy, dry, and red skin with crusty scales, cracks, or blisters. It may look different on various shades of skin. (Photo Credit: Science Source)
Dermatitis vs. psoriasis

Psoriasis is a type of dermatitis. In this case, your body makes skin cells in days rather than weeks, which means the skin cells will pile up on parts of your skin as thick, scaly, silver-looking patches. These patches can appear anywhere on your body but are most common on the knees, elbows, lower back, and scalp. They tend to be itchy, and the itchiness can become severe without treatment. Psoriasis is an ongoing (chronic) condition which has no cure.
If you have psoriasis, it tends to flare up when you have an infection, get a cut or burn, are exposed to smoke, drink heavily, or take certain medicines. Cold weather can also make it flare up.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Types
content: There are many different dermatitis skin conditions:

Allergic contact dermatitis is an allergic reaction to something that touches your skin, even for a brief time. Poison ivy is an example. It only has to brush against your skin to cause a rash. Many other plants can cause allergic contact dermatitis, such as certain flowers, herbs, fruits, and vegetables. Other triggers include fragrances, hair dyes, metals, rubber, formaldehyde (used as a preservative in many products), and skin care products.

Irritant contact dermatitis is caused by harsh substances, such as detergents or cleaning products, coming into contact with your skin. Other common skin irritants include body fluids such as pee or spit, hair dye, nail polish remover, plants such as peppers, paint, or some types of plastic or resin.

Nummular dermatitis consists of distinct coin-shaped red plaques that usually show up on your legs, hands, arms, and torso. You're more likely to get it if you're assigned male at birth (AMAB) and aged 55-65 years. Living in a dry climate or taking frequent, very hot showers can also be triggers.

sections.heading: Atopic dermatitis
content: is also known as eczema . It causes your skin to itch, scale, swell, and sometimes blister. It usually runs in families and is often linked to allergies, asthma, and stress. A weak skin barrier that allows moisture to escape and germs to enter may also play a part.

Seborrheic dermatitis , called cradle cap in infants, consists of greasy, yellowish, or reddish scaling on the scalp, face, or genitals. On the face, it typically appears in or near the eyebrows, hairline, or along the sides of the nose. Stress can make seborrheic dermatitis worse. Adults sometimes get s eborrheic dermatitis (also known as dandruff) on the scalp.

Stasis dermatitis is caused by poor circulation in your legs. You might get it if you have varicose veins, congestive heart failure , or another condition that causes chronic leg swelling. When the veins in your lower legs fail to return blood to your heart effectively, your blood pools, and fluid builds up. This leads to irritated, darkened skin, especially around your ankles.

sections.heading: Dyshidrotic dermatitis
content: is an ongoing condition that causes severely dry skin and bumps or blisters. You'll mostly see it on your hands or feet, and it may come and go. You're more likely to get it if you're assigned female at birth (AFAB) and between the ages of 20 and 40. Sweat, allergies, and stress could all be triggers.
Neurodermatitis is a very itchy patch of skin. Scratching it irritates the nerve endings, which causes the area to itch more. It might be severe enough to prevent you from sleeping.

Dermatitis neglecta is the result of not cleaning your skin well. Dirt, oil, bacteria, skin flakes, and sweat build up over time. The area could become thick and change color. You could also see sticky, cornflake-like scales. This is more likely to happen if you can't move well enough to regularly wash certain parts of your body.

Spongiotic dermatitis is when your irritated skin becomes "spongy" due to fluids building up underneath it. If you've been dealing with skin issues for a while, the swelling may be mild. But if your skin gets red and itchy all of a sudden, for instance, because of contact with an allergen , the swelling could be severe. Spongiotic dermatitis can exist alongside many other types of dermatitis.

sections.heading: Diaper dermatitis
content: is another name for diaper rash. Poop and pee irritate your baby's skin, especially if their diaper is not changed often enough, or if they're on antibiotics. The skin in your baby's diaper area will usually look red and shiny. Other causes of diaper rash are candida (a yeast infection ) and s eborrheic dermatitis, which can affect the diaper area.

Perioral/periorificial dermatitis is a red rash around your mouth. You might have scaly skin and small inflamed bumps that look like acne. The condition may spread from your mouth to your nose, eyes, and rarely, your genitals. It mostly affects young adult women. The exact cause is unknown, but doctors see a link between topical steroids (steroid creams applied on the skin) and perioral dermatitis. Other possible causes include face creams, fluoride toothpaste, chewing gum, dental fillings, and sunscreen. Doctors also think female hormones might play a role.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Symptoms
content: How your skin looks and feels will depend on the type of dermatitis you have. You could have more than one kind at the same time. Symptoms include:

Your symptoms can vary based on the color of your skin. For instance, if you have lighter skin, a dermatitis rash often looks red. If your skin is darker, you might have d ark brown, purple, or gray patches. You're also more likely to get tiny, rough bumps.
bullets: Blisters that may be filled with fluid
A burning feeling in your skin

content_blocks.text: How your skin looks and feels will depend on the type of dermatitis you have. You could have more than one kind at the same time. Symptoms include:
associated_bullets: Blisters that may be filled with fluid
A burning feeling in your skin

sections.heading: What Causes Dermatitis?
content: Dermatitis is a complex condition. There's a lot that doctors are still trying to learn about it. So far, they know that changes in your skin cause it to lose moisture, which can make it dry and itchy. The more you scratch, the drier and more itchy your skin becomes.
Many factors can also add to this, including:
Your immune system. If it overreacts to something you come into contact with, your skin can become inflamed.
Your genes. You might have been born with skin that struggles to maintain a healthy amount of moisture.

sections.heading: Your environment.
content: Some substances trigger changes in your skin. Among them are tobacco smoke , air pollutants, and scents in soaps and other skin products.

Stress and hormones. When you're in a stressful situation, your body produces more stress hormones such as cortisol. Too much cortisol can suppress the immune system and cause your skin to get inflamed.
Is dermatitis contagious?
Although your skin may look very inflamed and feel itchy, you can't spread your skin rash to others.
Even poison ivy rashes aren't contagious. You have to come into direct contact with urushiol oil, the compound inside the plant that triggers your immune system.

Even poison ivy rashes aren't contagious. You have to come into direct contact with urushiol oil, the compound inside the plant that triggers your immune system.

sections.heading: Risk Factors for Dermatitis
content: You're more likely to have dermatitis because of your:
Family history. If you're related to someone with dermatitis, you're more likely to get it. A history of asthma and allergies in your family can also raise your risk.
Gender. People who are AFAB are more prone to dermatitis.
Age. Kids and babies are more likely to have dermatitis than adults. Atopic dermatitis is most likely to be seen in non-Hispanic Black children.
Job. Working, for instance, with some types of metal or harsh chemicals could irritate your skin.
Health. Living with another health condition, such as an autoimmune disease, could make you more likely to get dermatitis.

content_blocks.text: You're more likely to have dermatitis because of your:

Age. Kids and babies are more likely to have dermatitis than adults. Atopic dermatitis is most likely to be seen in non-Hispanic Black children.
Job. Working, for instance, with some types of metal or harsh chemicals could irritate your skin.
Health. Living with another health condition, such as an autoimmune disease, could make you more likely to get dermatitis.

sections.heading: Diagnosing Dermatitis
content: Your doctor will probably start your visit by asking a lot of questions, such as:
bullets: Do you, or anyone in your family, have allergies or asthma?
What other skin issues have you had?
Have you used any new soap, detergent, makeup, or other skin products?
Do you smoke or have you been around cigarette smoke?

content_blocks.text: Your doctor will probably start your visit by asking a lot of questions, such as:
associated_bullets: Do you, or anyone in your family, have allergies or asthma?
What other skin issues have you had?
Have you used any new soap, detergent, makeup, or other skin products?
Do you smoke or have you been around cigarette smoke?

content: After they look at your skin, they could decide to get more information by doing a:
Skin biopsy. A tiny piece of your skin is taken off and sent to a lab, where it can be looked at more closely.
Blood test. This can look for conditions aside from dermatitis that may be causing your symptoms.

Patch test for allergies. Patches that contain very small amounts of common allergens are stuck to your skin. After a few days, you'll go back to your doctor. They'll remove the patches and check your skin for a reaction.
To figure out the cause of your skin issue, you may need to see a dermatologist. This type of doctor has special training in skin-related issues.

Health. Living with another health condition, such as an autoimmune disease, could make you more likely to get dermatitis.

content_blocks.text: You're more likely to have dermatitis because of your:
Family history. If you're related to someone with dermatitis, you're more likely to get it. A history of asthma and allergies in your family can also raise your risk.
Gender. People who are AFAB are more prone to dermatitis.
Age. Kids and babies are more likely to have dermatitis than adults. Atopic dermatitis is most likely to be seen in non-Hispanic Black children.
Job. Working, for instance, with some types of metal or harsh chemicals could irritate your skin.
Health. Living with another health condition, such as an autoimmune disease, could make you more likely to get dermatitis.

sections.heading: Diagnosing Dermatitis
content: Your doctor will probably start your visit by asking a lot of questions, such as:
bullets: Do you, or anyone in your family, have allergies or asthma?
What other skin issues have you had?
Have you used any new soap, detergent, makeup, or other skin products?
Do you smoke or have you been around cigarette smoke?

content_blocks.text: Your doctor will probably start your visit by asking a lot of questions, such as:
associated_bullets: Do you, or anyone in your family, have allergies or asthma?
What other skin issues have you had?
Have you used any new soap, detergent, makeup, or other skin products?
Do you smoke or have you been around cigarette smoke?

content: After they look at your skin, they could decide to get more information by doing a:
Skin biopsy. A tiny piece of your skin is taken off and sent to a lab, where it can be looked at more closely.
Blood test. This can look for conditions aside from dermatitis that may be causing your symptoms.

Patch test for allergies. Patches that contain very small amounts of common allergens are stuck to your skin. After a few days, you'll go back to your doctor. They'll remove the patches and check your skin for a reaction.
To figure out the cause of your skin issue, you may need to see a dermatologist. This type of doctor has special training in skin-related issues.

Blood test. This can look for conditions aside from dermatitis that may be causing your symptoms.

Patch test for allergies. Patches that contain very small amounts of common allergens are stuck to your skin. After a few days, you'll go back to your doctor. They'll remove the patches and check your skin for a reaction.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Treatment
content: The skin treatment you need depends on the type of skin condition you have, what may be causing it, and which parts of your body are affected.
Home treatment
Sometimes, a skin rash will clear up with some simple home remedies, such as:

content_blocks.text: The skin treatment you need depends on the type of skin condition you have, what may be causing it, and which parts of your body are affected.
Home treatment
Sometimes, a skin rash will clear up with some simple home remedies, such as:

sections.heading: Anti-itch cream or ointment.
content: Look for a kind that contains at least 1% hydrocortisone. Apply it once or twice a day.

Moisturizer. It's important to protect your skin from getting drier so it can heal. Don't forget to apply moisturizer right after you bathe or shower. Some people find petroleum jelly (although messy) works well.
Antihistamines. Over-the-counter drugs, such as Benadryl, are sometimes enough to ease itching. Check with your doctor so you know which kind will work best and be safe for you to use.
Cool compresses. A washcloth that's been soaked in cold water can give instant itch relief.
Bleach baths. Put a small amount (1/4 cup) of bleach into a warm bath, soak for 10 minutes, then rinse off. But don't try this without talking to your doctor first.
Soft, loose clothes. When your skin is inflamed, itchy, rough fabrics and tight clothes can rub against the area and make it worse.
Tea tree oil shampoo. Using this type of shampoo for 4 weeks can help improve dandruff.

Soft, loose clothes. When your skin is inflamed, itchy, rough fabrics and tight clothes can rub against the area and make it worse.
Tea tree oil shampoo. Using this type of shampoo for 4 weeks can help improve dandruff.

sections.heading: Trying to relax.
content: Stress and worry could make your skin condition worse. Eat healthy foods, try to get regular exercise, and get enough sleep to keep your stress levels low. Other stress-lowering techniques include yoga, meditation, acupuncture, and massage.

Staying cool. Sweat can make your skin itch and increase the risk of bacteria. Use air conditioning in the summer. During the winter, too much dry air may cause your skin to itch, so use a humidifier to keep the air moderate and moist.

Lukewarm baths. Don't make your showers too hot or long. This will strip your skin of its natural oils that protect it. Lukewarm showers or baths are better. Either one is equally effective as long as they're just 5-10 minutes long and you apply moisturizer within 3 minutes of coming out of the bath/shower.

sections.heading: Oatmeal baths.
content: To soothe your skin, add colloidal oatmeal to your bath and soak for no more than 10 minutes. Colloidal oatmeal is oatmeal ground very fine so it can dissolve in water. You can buy the product at the drugstore or grind up whole uncooked oats in your blender until it becomes powder. You can also mix it into a paste and apply it directly to your skin.

content_blocks.text: To soothe your skin, add colloidal oatmeal to your bath and soak for no more than 10 minutes. Colloidal oatmeal is oatmeal ground very fine so it can dissolve in water. You can buy the product at the drugstore or grind up whole uncooked oats in your blender until it becomes powder. You can also mix it into a paste and apply it directly to your skin.

sections.heading: Mild soap.
content: Look for soaps that are mild and fragrance-free, or for non-soap cleansers such as Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser or CeraVe Hydrating Cleanser Bar. These tend to be less irritating to the skin.
Medical treatment

If your skin doesn't clear up with home treatment, or if it's painful, disturbing your daily routine, keeping you up at night, or showing signs of infection (such as pus, streaks, or scabs), see a doctor. They could prescribe:

Creams or ointments. Put these on your rash to ease your itching, reduce inflammation , or restore your skin's natural barrier so it holds on to more moisture. Examples include calcineurin inhibitors, corticosteroids, PDE4 inhibitors, Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors, topical antihistamines for itching, topical antibiotics for infections, and topical tar preparations for seborrheic dermatitis.
Light therapy. This uses a controlled amount of ultraviolet light to reduce itching and redness.

Pills you take by mouth . Oral corticosteroids are a common way to help control inflammation throughout your body. In some cases, your doctor may want you to take antibiotics. Other oral drugs include PDE4 inhibitors, antihistamines, antifungals, and JAK inhibitors.

content_blocks.text: Look for soaps that are mild and fragrance-free, or for non-soap cleansers such as Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser or CeraVe Hydrating Cleanser Bar. These tend to be less irritating to the skin.

Pills you take by mouth . Oral corticosteroids are a common way to help control inflammation throughout your body. In some cases, your doctor may want you to take antibiotics. Other oral drugs include PDE4 inhibitors, antihistamines, antifungals, and JAK inhibitors.

sections.heading: Injected medicines.
content: For instance, you could get a shot of a biologic drug, which is made from living cells, to slow your immune system.
Wet dressings. You apply a strong ointment to your rash, then cover it with layers of wet and dry bandages, to help your skin heal.
Alternative treatment
You could also talk to your doctor about an alternative treatment. These methods aren't as well-known or as well-studied as traditional options but have been helpful for some people.

Coconut oil. Its anti-inflammatory substances could help improve your skin, but check with your doctor before applying it on your rash. If you have an allergic reaction, it could make your symptoms worse.

sections.heading: Chinese herbs.
content: A few studies have shown that carefully prepared Chinese herbs can help with some types of dermatitis, though the studies were of poor quality. Talk to your doctor to find out if this is a safe option for you.
Acupuncture. This form of Chinese medicine involves very thin needles placed just under your skin. There's some evidence that it can help with itching and other skin symptoms.

content_blocks.text: A few studies have shown that carefully prepared Chinese herbs can help with some types of dermatitis, though the studies were of poor quality. Talk to your doctor to find out if this is a safe option for you.
Acupuncture. This form of Chinese medicine involves very thin needles placed just under your skin. There's some evidence that it can help with itching and other skin symptoms.

sections.heading: Hypnosis.
content: Although more research needs to be done, one study found that it helped reduce itching and scratching more than a steroid cream .

Biofeedback. A special device can help you learn how to control your breathing and heart rate so you can better manage stress. Learning this mind-body technique could help with itching and other skin symptoms.

Supplements. Some people find that vitamin D, fish oil, zinc, selenium, turmeric, probiotics, and evening primrose oil help reduce inflammation and boost the immune system. Let your doctor know if you decide to take any of these, as some have side effects or interact badly with certain medications.

content_blocks.text: Although more research needs to be done, one study found that it helped reduce itching and scratching more than a steroid cream .

Supplements. Some people find that vitamin D, fish oil, zinc, selenium, turmeric, probiotics, and evening primrose oil help reduce inflammation and boost the immune system. Let your doctor know if you decide to take any of these, as some have side effects or interact badly with certain medications.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Prevention
content: Taking care of your skin is the best way to prevent dermatitis. To do that:
Keep your showers short. Use lukewarm (not hot) water so you don't dry out your skin.

Use mild skin care products. Look for ones that don't contain perfumes, alcohol, or dyes. If you're not sure what to use, ask your doctor to suggest a brand. If you have dermatitis on your face, some types of makeup could make it worse. Skip it or choose products made for sensitive skin.

content_blocks.text: Taking care of your skin is the best way to prevent dermatitis. To do that:
Keep your showers short. Use lukewarm (not hot) water so you don't dry out your skin.

Use mild skin care products. Look for ones that don't contain perfumes, alcohol, or dyes. If you're not sure what to use, ask your doctor to suggest a brand. If you have dermatitis on your face, some types of makeup could make it worse. Skip it or choose products made for sensitive skin.

sections.heading: Go easy on your skin.
content: Skip loofahs, pumice stones , or scrubs that might irritate your skin. And when you get out of the shower, pat, don't rub, your skin dry.
Lock in moisture. Apply an unscented cream or moisturizer soon after you shower and throughout the day.
Manage your stress. Your emotions can affect your skin, so explore ways to keep your stress in check. Meditation, relaxation techniques, and therapy could all make a positive difference.

Consider dietary changes. There's a link between eating certain foods and dermatitis flare-ups, but it's not straightforward. You may not have any other reactions (such as breaking into hives), or the flare-up might happen hours after eating. Some people get relief from atopic dermatitis by eliminating gluten and/or dairy from their diet, even though clinical studies haven't found evidence for this. Others get relief from contact dermatitis by avoiding foods high in nickel (such as whole wheat grains, shellfish, legumes, and chocolate). Consider doing an allergy test, and talk to your doctor and nutritionist about the best diet for you.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Complications
content: Although a skin rash may sound mild, you can get serious complications from dermatitis. These include:

Viral skin infections. Dermatitis makes you vulnerable to viral skin infections. If you have the herpes simplex virus and dermatitis, you're at risk for a severe skin infection called eczema herpeticum. Don't get a smallpox vaccine if you have dermatitis, because it can cause another serious skin infection called eczema vaccinatum .

Bacterial skin infections. Some 60%-90% of people with atopic dermatitis (eczema) are likely to have staph bacteria on their skin, which can develop into a serious bodily infection. Scratching adds to the risk of bacterial infection entering your body.

Sleep loss. Atopic dermatitis is associated with sleep problems in 47%-80% of children and 33%-90% of adults. The reasons are not completely clear. A common explanation is that itching and scratching keep people awake, and if you're prone to insomnia, this combo only makes it worse.

Conjunctivitis. People with dermatitis are much more likely to get conjunctivitis (inflammation or redness of the eye). The same factors that irritate your skin (such as allergies) can also irritate your eyes.

Blepharitis. This is a condition where your eyelids get swollen or inflamed. It has many causes, including allergies, lice/mites, and dandruff. Dandruff (seborrheic dermatitis) flaking can irritate your eyelids.

content_blocks.text: Although a skin rash may sound mild, you can get serious complications from dermatitis. These include:

Viral skin infections. Dermatitis makes you vulnerable to viral skin infections. If you have the herpes simplex virus and dermatitis, you're at risk for a severe skin infection called eczema herpeticum. Don't get a smallpox vaccine if you have dermatitis, because it can cause another serious skin infection called eczema vaccinatum .

Bacterial skin infections. Some 60%-90% of people with atopic dermatitis (eczema) are likely to have staph bacteria on their skin, which can develop into a serious bodily infection. Scratching adds to the risk of bacterial infection entering your body.

Sleep loss. Atopic dermatitis is associated with sleep problems in 47%-80% of children and 33%-90% of adults. The reasons are not completely clear. A common explanation is that itching and scratching keep people awake, and if you're prone to insomnia, this combo only makes it worse.

Conjunctivitis. People with dermatitis are much more likely to get conjunctivitis (inflammation or redness of the eye). The same factors that irritate your skin (such as allergies) can also irritate your eyes.

Blepharitis. This is a condition where your eyelids get swollen or inflamed. It has many causes, including allergies, lice/mites, and dandruff. Dandruff (seborrheic dermatitis) flaking can irritate your eyelids.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Dermatitis doesn't have a cure, but there are many ways you can manage pain, itching, and other symptoms. Some methods include anti-itch creams, antihistamines, and prescription drugs. You may need to try a few different treatments before you find the one that heals your skin. Once you do, take care of your skin to try to prevent further flare-ups.

content_blocks.text: Dermatitis doesn't have a cure, but there are many ways you can manage pain, itching, and other symptoms. Some methods include anti-itch creams, antihistamines, and prescription drugs. You may need to try a few different treatments before you find the one that heals your skin. Once you do, take care of your skin to try to prevent further flare-ups.

sections.heading: Dermatitis FAQs
content: Will dermatitis cause scars?

Dermatitis doesn't directly cause scars. But if you, for instance, scratch the spot where you have eczema, it can lead to bleeding, and as the area heals, it leaves a scar. If your skin is dark, the scar is more noticeable. The scars usually fade over time.
How long does dermatitis last?

It depends on the type. Atopic dermatitis usually lasts 1-3 weeks. Contact dermatitis lasts 2-4 weeks. Seborrheic dermatitis could last months to years. Regardless of the type, you could have flare-ups throughout your lifetime.

content_blocks.text: Will dermatitis cause scars?

How long does dermatitis last?

It depends on the type. Atopic dermatitis usually lasts 1-3 weeks. Contact dermatitis lasts 2-4 weeks. Seborrheic dermatitis could last months to years. Regardless of the type, you could have flare-ups throughout your lifetime.

sections.heading: Dermatitis Complications
content: Although a skin rash may sound mild, you can get serious complications from dermatitis. These include:

Viral skin infections. Dermatitis makes you vulnerable to viral skin infections. If you have the herpes simplex virus and dermatitis, you're at risk for a severe skin infection called eczema herpeticum. Don't get a smallpox vaccine if you have dermatitis, because it can cause another serious skin infection called eczema vaccinatum .

Bacterial skin infections. Some 60%-90% of people with atopic dermatitis (eczema) are likely to have staph bacteria on their skin, which can develop into a serious bodily infection. Scratching adds to the risk of bacterial infection entering your body.

Sleep loss. Atopic dermatitis is associated with sleep problems in 47%-80% of children and 33%-90% of adults. The reasons are not completely clear. A common explanation is that itching and scratching keep people awake, and if you're prone to insomnia, this combo only makes it worse.

Conjunctivitis. People with dermatitis are much more likely to get conjunctivitis (inflammation or redness of the eye). The same factors that irritate your skin (such as allergies) can also irritate your eyes.

Blepharitis. This is a condition where your eyelids get swollen or inflamed. It has many causes, including allergies, lice/mites, and dandruff. Dandruff (seborrheic dermatitis) flaking can irritate your eyelids.

sections.heading: Is there a cure for dermatitis?
content: It depends on the type, but generally, there is no cure â only management of flare-ups.

content_blocks.text: It depends on the type, but generally, there is no cure â only management of flare-ups.

sections.heading: What is the best treatment for contact dermatitis rash?
content: The best contact dermatitis rash treatment is to use a prescription steroid cream, such as clobetasol 0.05% or triamcinolone 0.1%, that you apply to the affected skin area. If the rash is very severe or widespread, your doctor may give you steroid pills to take, such as prednisone.

meta_description: Dermatitis is a skin condition causing inflammation, redness, and itching, often due to allergies or irritants. Find expert insights and advice on managing dermatitis
